We take pleasure in presenting to the public the second volume of the Bruns wick City Directory. The City Directory is more than a list of residents, with

their occupations and addresses; it is a complete and accurate guide to the city, its people, their government, their institutions, organizations and societies. It is a complete record of all the persons and places of the day and becomes a' perma nent history of the city and its people. It has been the aim of the publishers to make the Brunswick City Directory a medium to display the progress the city is making in business and population. There is no publication connected with the city which so completely exhibits the industrial, commercial and other industries than the City Directory. The statements set forth are taken from facts and can

not be successfully contradicted. The following interesting sketch is presented through the courtesy ot the

Brunswick Board of Trade:

.

c ,

Brunswick was founded in 1771 by order of the Colonial Council. The hrst

survey of the new city was made one year previous to that date and the hrst

lot was sold in 1772.

.

,

,

, , , ,

Brunswick is located at the apex of the great inward curve of the Atlantic

Coast, the Florida peninsula extending to the southeast and eastern shore of

the United States extending to the north-east. The city proper is built upon a

peninsula, whose shores are washed by tidal streams. Practically no fie si

flows into the sea in the neighborhood of Brunswick. > Brunswick Harbor, as it is officially known, comprises the Waterways, ot.

Simon Sound, Brunswick River. Turtle River, East River, and Academy Cree , only one of which is an alluvial bearing stream, the rest being estuaries of the

sea' It is located &t the entrant angle of the southeast coast of the United States, and by its geographical location makes possible the most economical freight rates. Tt is situated midway between two large navigable rivers, which practically attord the drainage for all of Southeast Georgia, namely, the Altamaha River system,

12 miles to the northward, and the Greater Satilla River, 12 miles tothe south

ward. An idea of the size and capacity ofthe harbor mav he had from the fol lowing figures: Inside of the bar proper, and up to the Southern Railway dock located at the extreme inner end, there is found an anchorage basin 7 rmles in length, with a width of 300 to .3.000 feet, with depths ranging from 30 to 8? feet which forms an area of some T.030 acres all of which is land-locked, or at Fast protected from heavy weather. The loading docks now existing m the harbor

are situated from eleven to twenty miles from the deep water outside of the bar. The rise and fall of the tide ranges from a little less than seven feet on the bar to a little more than seven feet at the upper end of the harbor. Up to this date there has been obtained a channel across Brunswick Bar in straight line from the St. Simon's Lighthouse and leading uppast the entire water frontand to the Southern Railway docks, having a width of 400 feet, a depth of 30 feet at mean

high water.

.

. .

. .

The natural beauty of Brunswick is peerless among American cities. he

harbor is the most beautiful on the Atlantic Coast. The broad expanse of the

hay is broken here and there by wide stretches of tidal meadows, while higher

land, heavily wooded with giant oaks and picturesque palms, lends just the varia

tion necessary as a final romantic touch. Grand live oak trees that the eaily set

tlers found growing in Brunswick have never been disturbed. Scores of them

are still growing in various parts of the city. Driveways and car lines are turned

aside for them. The natural beauty of the city has been carefully preserved while

at the same time everything that could be done has been added to nature s efforts.

B anking F acilities-- The combined resources of the three banks of Bruns

wick exceeds $2,000,000.00.

,

P ublic B uildings-- The public buildings of Brunswick are fine types of archi

tectural beauty. They have been built for permanency and for the improvement

of the town as much as for their individual usefulness. The Federal building or

Custom House and Post Office cost $150,000.00. The City Hall cost $75,000.00.

The Glynn County Court House cost $150,000.00. The Brunswick Hospital build ing and equipment cost $65,000.00.

P ublic H ea l th -- In community health the city of Brunswick leads American seaport towns. It is in every respect a healthy resort. The death rate of its

whole population for the year 1913 is 11.9 to the thousand. The death rate among

the white population from tuberculosis in 1912 was less than 4 per cent of alb

deaths, as opposed to 10 per cent in the registration area of the United States.

The entire absence of fresh water streams in the vicinity of Brunswick and

the seven foot rise and fall of the tide washing the shore together with the salt marshes about the city insure safety from mosquitoes and malaria. The health

fulness of Brunswick is also safeguarded by the water supply which is derived from flowing artesian wells.

The Waring system of sewerage personally installed by the great engineer

himself is among the city's most important protections against disease. This

sewerage system was built for utility and efficiency. Cost was a minor considera tion. Year after year the absence of contagious diseases and low death rate prove

the wisdom of the city officials of Brunswick who insisted that the sewerage

system of Brunswick should be the best.

The city maintains a well equipped laboratory in charge of the City Health

officer who makes regular inspections of school children, and of the sources of

milk and other foods.

C h u r ch es-- Brunswick has eleven churches, each possessing a very attractive church building. The total church membership of Brunswick is 2,500. The total

cost of all the church buildings is $175,000.00

P a r k s-- Eighteen attractive parks and squares, several of them of considera ble area and all well cared for, are located in different sections of the city. Their

beauty adds a great deal to the attractiveness of the city.

S treets an d S id e w a lk s-- The streets of the business section o f Brunswick

are paved with vitrified brick. Residence streets and suburban drives are paved with shell. Every important sidewalk in the city has been paved.

C lim ate-- The even semi-tropical climate of Brunswick is one of its strongest attractions. The mean temperature for the winter months is 54; for the spring

months, 67; for the summer months, 80; for the fall months, 69; average for

the year, 67.8 The average annual rainfall is 51 inches. The average date of

the first frost is December 5th, and of the last frost is February 20th. The first

frost frequently comes as late as early January, while the last frost not infre quently comes in early February.

S ocial C lu b s-- Brunswick has several social organizations and clubs, each with rooms or a home. The Elks Club is housed in a pretty building near the

Postoffice on a very large lot and sets well back from the street which it fronts

on two sides. The building and furnishings cost $25,000.00.

P ublic S chools-- The public school system of Brunswick is a source of great pride to the city. The buildings are modern in every detail including sanitation,

fire safety and accessibility. Included in the system are one high school and two

grammar schools and a school for negroes. In the county there are thirty-two

schools for whites. The schools of the county and city are free. Free public schools were provided for in the Act of the Colonial Council creating Brunswick

and from that time to the present they have been free.

Glynn County is perhaps the only county in the State whose schools have for

124 years been maintained without tuition. This long record of free public schools

accounts to a great extent for the fact that, according to the United States Cen

sus for 1900, the percentage of illiteracy in Glynn County among native whites

over twenty-one years old is the lowest among all Georgia counties. Among the

negroes the percentage is also lowest among Georgia counties with but two ex ceptions. Only 2.4 per cent of native whites of Glynn County are illiterate.

B u ilding A ctivity-- Brunswick steadily maintains its even growth. Building

permits for the past seven years have averaged $220,000.00 per year. Buildings

now in course of construction or contracted for total in value $150,000.00, is as sured during the next twelve months.

J e k y l I sland-- In sight of the wharves at Brunswick is Jekyl Island, the

winter home and resort of the Jekyl Island Club, a social organization of Ameri

can capitalists. The club owns the entire island, and besides making it the most unique game preserve in America, having stocked it with game from two hemis

pheres, has also erected magnificent homes for members. To such an extent have

these improvements and landscape gardening, shelled roads, and boat landings

added to the beauty of Jekyl Island that it is become "The Riviera of America."

R ailroads, S t e a m s h ip L in e s an d P u blic H ig h w a y s -- In transportation fa cilities the port of Brunswick is unsurpassed. Four railroads serve the port as follows: The Southern Railway of 7,485 miles; the Atlanta, Birmingham & Atlantic Railway of 625 miles; the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad with 4,322 miles; the Georgia Coast and Piedmont Railroad, a 100-mile trunk line connecting Bruns wick with five independent lines, whose total length exceeds 600 miles. In ad dition to these the Seaboard Air Line Railroad in connection with the Atlanta, Birmingham & Atlantic Railroad via Thalmann makes practically a fifth system entering Brunswick. Through these routes Brunswick is intimately connected with every part of the United States. Two steamship lines serve the port. The Strachan Line, operated by F. D. M. Strachan & Company between Brunswick and Europe, the West Indies, and South America, and the Mallory Line, making regular sailings from Brunswick to the South Atlantic, the Gulf of Mexico, and to New York. Five steamship companies operate lines to Cumberland Island and Fernandina, to Jekyl Island, St. Simons Island, Darien to points on the Altamaha River and tributaries, and the Satilla River points. Local transportation is pro vided for by an excellent electric street railway system in the city and by fine shell roads through the country. Glynn County has a greater percentage of its public roads permanently improved than any other county in Georgia. The Seminole frail, the highway from New York to the East Coast of Florida, passes through Brunswick. Hundreds of motorists make their Southern tour by that route.

A D istribu tin g P oint-- With five railroad systems reaching every important manufacturing center of the South and covering Georgia like a net, Brunswick bids for the distributing business of the South. Her railroads solicit this business and offer inducements. The coast terminal facilities of Brunswick are unequaled either on the Gulf Coast or on the Atlantic Coast south of Norfolk. Additional improvements under construction will place Brunswick even further in advance

of rival points. Jobbing P oint-- The annual jobbing trade of Brunswick, including trade

in machinery, mill supplies, groceries, and dry goods, exceeds $10,000,000, and is rapidly growing. South Georgia, which is immediately tributary to Brunswick, is building up faster than any other part of the South today. Seventy-five per cent of the farms in South Georgia are free from mortgage debt. Between 1900 and 1910 the total value of all farm property in South Georgia increased 180 per cent; the total value of all farm lands 190 per cent; the average value of farm land per acre 150 per cent; the total number of farms increased 37 per cent. Brunswick is the port and jobbing point for this section and its business grows

as the county back of it grows. S t. S im on I sland-- St. Simon Island lies between the Altamaha River and St.

Simon Sound, separated from the mainland by McCoy's River. It has been called the "Cradle of American Liberty." More historic than any of the islands around Brunswick, and not exclusive to a limited number of people, it is the joy of thousands of inhabitants from the interior of the Southern and Middle Western States, who flock to its surf and invigorating climate in the summer months, from May to October. The island is twelve miles long and three miles wide and has a beautiful beach line eight miles long with unsurpassed surf bathing. It has a large new summer hotel and several smaller ones, and over three hundred private cottages, many of which may be leased for the season, where the summer months are whiled away most delightfully. The same natural and climatic conditions of jekyl Island exist at St. Simon. The island is traversed in several directions by beautiful shell roads that lead to points of historic interest. Frederica, the earliest settlement in Georgia being one of them. Frederica was founded by General Oglethorpe. Ruins of fortifications constructed by him are still standing. Near Frederica lies the battle-field of Bloody Marsh, where a small English force under Oglethorpe defeated a large army of Spanish invaders, saving Georgia to the English Crown. St. Simon was also the first American home of the Wesley's,

founders of Methodism. Points of interest associated with the Wesleys may

be seen. T e r m in als-- The Atlanta, Birmingham & Atlantic Railroad Coast Terminals

cover 25 acres and employ 300 men. They have three basins, giving a dock front age of 3,500 feet for boats drawing 30 feet. Four warehouses, with 24,000 square feet of space in each with six miles of track touching all parts of the terminals. A 20-ton ice plant furnishes ice for ships and cars carrying perishable consign ment. These terminals cost $3,000,000. They are located ten miles from open sea, and one mile from the center of the city.

In addition to large wharves in the city, the Southern Railway has 4,200 feet front at its Turtle River docks with 26 to 27 foot water at low tide alongside. Here it has warehouses for 25,000 bales of cotton and other export traffic, equipped

with up-to-date fire apparatus, chemical extinguishers, fire walls, etc. At this dock an immense warehouse of 30,000 tons capacity has just been constructed for import bulk material, having electrially driven overhead tramways giving a total capacity of about 40,000 tons for import bulk material.

ih e Atlantic Coast Line Railroad docks are centrally located with the joint A. C. L.-Southern Railway yards, twenty-eight hundred feet of improved and three thousand feet of unimproved water frontage, equipped with parallel and lateral tracks, as well as other facilities for rapid and economical handling of lumber, cross-ties, naval stores, etc., also equipped with splendid offices on the premises for permanent tenants. Vessels of any draught that come to the port can load and clear at these terminals. Operated either under contract or open wharfage basis.

The docks of the Georgia Coast & Piedmont Railriod, a hundred mile trunk line affording entrance to the port for five railroads aggregating over six hundred miles of track with no port connections over their own rails, face 2,000 feet along the government 30-feet harbor channel. These docks handle ties, timber, naval stores and cotton which move out over the newly established Baltimore and Brunswick Line to the port of Baltimore. Commodious warehouses store a large volume of produce for eastern manufacturing centers which are handled South on this steamship line and from Brunswick are distributed throughout the entire southeast.

C ommerce-- The water-born commerce of Brunswick annually exceeds $50,000,000 in value.

The exports of the port increased 31.6 per cent for the year ending January xst, 1913-

I ndustries-- The Yaryan Naval Stores Company, producers of rosin, turpen tine and by-products, leads the industrial activities of Brunswick. This plant represents an investment of $1,000,000 and is more than three times as large as any other similar plant in the world. One thousand seven hundred employees are on its pay roll. The annual distribution of wages by this plant exceeds $600,000. The plant of the Georgia Veneer and Package Company, and that of the Bruns wick Creosoting Company, the first manufacturing box shook, fruit cases and crates, and the second treating with creosote the equivalent of $50,000,000 b. m. feet of lumber per annum, comes next to the Yaryan Company in importance. The other manufacturing industries of Brunswick are large marine repair works, a marine railway a furnitue factory, sheet metal works, the plant of the Glynn Canning Company, publishing houses, planing mills, contractors and pile drivers, barrel factories, machine shops, broom factories, lumber mills, handle factories, foundries, fertilizer factories, electrical contractors, cooper works, cement stone works, cigar factories, bottling plants, carriage works, and bakeries. Brunswick's monthly pay roll exceeds $200,000.

A d vantages for M an u fa c tu r in g -- Brunswick offers the manufacturer the following advantages: Low freight rates to the interior on finished products; low freight rates from the interior on raw material including wood and clays from nearby points, coal, iron, and steel from Alabama and Virginia; ample transportation facilities; flowing artesian water for manufacturing and domestic consumption; every condition essential to contented labor, such as good schools, good churches, numerous parks and play grounds, near by island resorts and surf bathing. There are no idle factories in Brunswick.

T imber-- Hard wood forests near Brunswick hold in store more than three billion cords of wood suitable for manufacturing into wood pulp, in the same forests there are many millions of feet of hard woods, available at reasonable prices, that can be manufactured into furniture at Brunswick.

S oils and A griculture-- The upland sails of Glynn County consists of ma terials washed from the hills to the west. These sediments, by waves and tides, were reworked into various sandy loams and subsequently further altered by erosion, the growth and decay of vegetation, and by chemical change. In places accumulation of vegetable matter built a deep rich muck. The subsoils in such places are usually mottled in color. The heavy soils have been formed by the deposition of salt and clay from the local streams and tides. The soils of the river bottoms are strictly alluvial in origin.

Transportation facilities for farm and truck garden products are good. Through refrigerator car service to the north and east is available. The following crops may be grown with profit in Glynn County near Brunswick: Corn, sugar cane, forage crops, celery, cabbage, lettuce, onions, Irish potatoes, sweet' potatoes or yams, tomatoes, egg plant, cow peas, radishes, beets, turnips, strawberries, pea nuts, oats rice, okra, both Sea Island and short staple cotton, English peas, velvet beans, soya beans, asparagus, cauliflower.

1

C itrus F ruits-- The soil and climate of Glynn County are adapted to citrus fruit growing. In the county and especially on the coastal islands many orange and grape fruit trees have been planted and are bearing fruit every year. Other fruits including pomegranites, figs, pears, peaches, and scuppernong grapes can

be cultured profitably. P ecan s-- The soils of Glynn County are peculiarly adopted to the growing

of pecans. Many fine groves have been planted and the industry is becoming

very popular. P rice of L and-- The greater part of available agricultural lands are easily

accessible by the splendid shell boulevards and may be purchased at reasonable prices. The range of price is determined by the proximity to Brunswick.

S ports and P a stim e s.-- A nine-hole golf course, splendidly placed in W ind sor Park, near the " Marsh o'Glynn" has been put in perfect condition and now is one of the finest in the South. An attractive club house with comfortable ap pointments is at the command of members and guests.

The coast region and the islands near Brunswick are a fine field for deer hunting. Bear may be found in the swamps from fifteen to forty miles distant. Field, wood and canebrake abound with quail, woodcock, rice-birds and doves. The marshes and tidal streams of the section attract countless ducks, wild-geese,

marsh hens and other aquatic fowl. All fish that frequent the South Atlantic are found in abundance in the

waters about Brunswick Flarbor. Fishing parties rent motor boats and secure the services of guides at almost any time and at reasonable rates. Among the fish found in these waters are: Channel bass, winter trout, drum, sheephead, whiting, rock fish, flounder, blue fish and mackerel.

Tidal estuaries of the sea hundreds of miles in extent ramify the coast re gions in the vicinity of Brunswick. These salt water streams wind in and out among scores of islands and through the marshes, and offer delightful motor boating. A hundred historical points can be visited in the motor boat. One may sail the same inlets that were familiar to blood-thirsty pirates of the Spanish main in the days of Captain Kidd. Or one may visit such points as Frederica, on St. Simon Island, where Oglethorpe established his first headquarters and built his English forts that still stand.

The New York-Florida automobile highway passes through Brunswick, and many miles of beautiful shell road invite the tourist to bring his motor car to Brunswick and enjoy the best there is in it.

B oard of T rade.

F. E. Twitty,. President; E. L. Stephens, First Vice-President; G. H. Smith, Second Vice-President; J. G. Weatherly, Secretary; E. C. Bruce, Treasurer. Executive Committee: F. E. Twitty, E. L. Stephens, E. C. Bruce, J. G. Weather ly, C. Miller. Directors: F. E. Twitty, E. L. Stephens, J. H. Hopkins, M. B. McKinnon, J. J. Lott, L. T. McKinnon, J. G. Weatherly, L. H. Haym, Albert Fendig, E. C. Bruce, C. H. Leavy, J. P. Davenport, A. L. Church, Geo. H. Smith,

C. Miller. The Brunswick Board of Trade has been very carefully organized and is

believed by its founders to be the most effective co-operative commercial organi zation in the county. Beginning with the President and Secretary the work of the organization quickly branches out through the five members of the Executive Committee, there again opening out fan-like among thirteen committees on each of which there must be at least one director. Each committee consists of three members, therefore twenty-six members are drawn from the ranks of the general organization and become advisors to the Directors. Hence the Executive officers of the organization are continually in sympathetic alignment with the general membership. Two members of the City Council and two members of the Board of County Commissioners must always be on the Directorate.

The function of a holding company is performed by the Brunswick Advance ment Association, a corporation which was organized prior to the Board of Trade and is really the parent organization. The effectiveness of the plan of organiza tion and the co-ordination of the active Board of Trade and the holding company has already been provided to the satisfaction of the people of Brunswick.

P opulation-- There are contained in this volume of the Directory 5,232 names. In estimating the population of the city, the multiple of three is used, indicat ing a population for Brunswick of 15,696.

Respectfully,

R. L. P O L K & C O M P A N Y,

Publishers.
